instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hi,

I have that board with an important liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and a slight one near <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>.
The board has quarter fan spin.
When the charger is plugged, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will come and then drop.

I've checked the current sensing resistors which measure fine.
I did reflow both areas and replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. Same issue.

I've replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, but same issue.

Looking for a short on the rails, I believe I have one on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> (0.04 on diode mode).
When I remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will stay on.

There are a few parts on this rail and the CPU, of course...
I will try to remove all the caps and chips on this rail and hope for the best.

What do you guys think?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
threads.message: What is resistance in Ohm on this rail? 0.04 in diode mode seems really low :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
threads.message: 44 ohm is not a problem on that rail. Is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> coming high?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
threads.message: Nope cause <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is dropping completely. It will remain only if I remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
threads.message: What does it do when a charged battery is connected?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage near <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
threads.message:
Thanks Duke! You're the king.
It was <CAPACITOR>C3618</CAPACITOR>. I could hear a transistor ticking once I plug the battery which was <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR>. Put some alcohol on the area and saw both the cap and the transistor were getting hot.
Removed the cap and good to go.

Easy to get dawn a rabbit hole though... I got tricked by this <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>
